*** If multiple members of our Portland group want to attend, we may be able to get a group rate.  RSVP to express interest and we can look into it. ***

Cost ranges from $275 up for all three days.  Full details here:

http://www.umasspermacultureconference.com/index.html

---------------------------

 

The UMass Permaculture Initiative proudly announces the Permaculture Your Campus Conference. This international conference is the first of its kind, connecting permaculture experts with groups who are brand new to planning sustainable, edible landscapes in a campus setting. 

Attendees to this conference receive expert guidance, as well as the tools, the time, and the space to develop a detailed plan for implementing their own permaculture landscapes, suited to each institution’s personalized needs.  Those attending also have the opportunity to network with other groups, leading to valuable, lasting partnerships with peer institutions just starting permaculture projects.  
  

The UMass Permaculture team is scheduled to present throughout the conference, offering their story as a case study for all those who come to learn about installing their own gardens. They also plan to discuss some permaculture basics and why permaculture landscapes make perfect sense in a campus setting. Looking at the economics of permaculture, they’ll also discuss how these ecological projects need only modest start-up costs and receive quick payback.  
Why attend?
Learn how campus permaculture landscapes make perfect sense economically as well as environmentally and socially. Permaculture is often the missing piece that connects these three elements and UMass Amherst offers a successful case study that you can easily replicate once we thoroughly examine it together.  

Permaculture landscapes..
1.) Are economically sustainable
2.) Need low start-up resources and have a quick payback
3.) Increase campus green visibility
4.) Produce high-quality, organic, local foods
5.) Increase triple bottom line sustainability
6.) Produce ecological, aesthetically-pleasing, edible landscapes
